name: Andicuri
description:
Andicuri beach, is one of Arubas number one surf spots. Mostly crowded by
bodyboarders it is a fun wedge type of wave. The wave is mostly a left
wedge but on big days the right jetty starts working. Its the most
consistent spot on the island with some nice hollow barrels and very fun
wedging ramps. Its for every level but on big days, experience is a must
because the wave gets very steep and throws really fast on the dry sand
bottom. Rides are generally short, but with good swell direction the side
waves get longer and connect better with the oncoming waves.

name: Boca Pistol
description: Reef-break, breaks left and right. Works on almost all swell directions. Short and powerful. Frequency high.

name: Boca Sint Joris
description: Sand-bar break. Breaks left and right. Works on almost all swells but tends to get messy fast. Works best on a hurricane swell.

name: Cazon (Buchuaco)
description: Beachbreak

name: Dos Playas
description:
One of the better known spots on Aruba, both for bodyboarding and surfing, Dos
Playa is located on the north coast in the Natural Reserve Park Arikok and
is easily accessible. The name Dos Playa translates literally to "Two
Beaches" because there are two large bays separated by large cliffs. The
wave is a beach break that breaks really close to the shore. The waves
breaks left and right giving some of the most consistent surfing on the
island.This spot is prone to bigger swells and is really hollow and
powerful and offers big ramps and big barrels. On big days is not
recommended for beginners.

name: Druif
description:
Boca Druif, located behind the Tierra del Sol golf course, is a slab that doubles up on itself.
Strictly a bodyboarding wave but some surfers have been known to charge it
on the good offshore days. It breaks on a very shallow reef and is very
steep, hollow and powerful. The main peak is mostly lefts but because it is
a very wide bay it offers some rights. On the far right side of the bay
there is jetty that turns into a sick little right hander wedge. On average
onshore days the wave is still pretty hollow and barreling but with shorter
rides. This spot prefers a north swell with low or south winds in order
to really turn on with long, big and hollow lefts. This spot is for
experienced surfers only and is usually uncrowded.

name: Dunes/Dooms
description:
One of the most picturesque of surfing spots on Aruba. Rarely busy, even
on weekends, Dunes or Dooms as the locals call it, is a classic surfing
spot. Behind you is wide beach, with a rugged coastline, and rustic
lighthouse; in front of you the never ending blue. It breaks over shallow
reef and can hold very big waves. Swells can get up to 7 or 8 feet if your
lucky. This is the go-to spot on those elusive after-hurricane swells.
Dangerous though. There is no channel whatsoever so you have to paddle
straight out through the white water . Sea urchins, rips, undertow and
rocks rule the area. This spot is for your average surfer but on big days
experience is a must.

name: El Palito
description: Best on an easterly swell

name: El Peaje
description: Beach break. Works best with little or no wind.

name: Guacuco
description: Beachbreak

name: Klein
description: When working the most famous and notorious spot on Curacao, situated on a small island off the coast, only accessible by boat. Works best on a North, Northeast swell with south-west to south-east wind directions. Works only a few times a year. Reef-break, only rights, very powerful, can barrel.

name: La Sabana
description: Classic right hand pointbreak. Breaks best from low to mid tide on a big swell.

name: Las Salinas
description: Beachbreak

name: Los Caracas
description: Classic right hand point break, river mouth, rocky botom, breaks all tides

name: Macuro
description: Best beach break in Puerto Cabello

name: Playa Kanoa
description: Reef break. Breaks left and right depending on swell direction. Breaks best on low tide on a northwestern swell.

name: Playa Los Cuatro
description: Beachbreak and reef

name: Playa Parguito
description: Covering all Margarita breaks

name: Puerto Cruz
description: Good right, only works from 4ft and upwards

name: Punta Arena
description: Beachbreak

name: Punta ballena
description: Needs a large swell

name: Rocky Point (Margarita)
description: A left

name: Taguantar
description: Beachbreak

name: Urirama
description:
A classic reef rocky spot, Urirama is a really small bay/inlet, located
near the old Alto Vista Chapel on the north coast. It is mostly a left and
very shallow with waves breaking all the way in to the small bay. Some waves
break in front of the rocky coast line.On good swell directions, waves
break both left and right, with good swells getting up to 5 or 6 feet. With
offshore winds, the waves turn on and are very hollow. The rocky coast line
provide some dangers because some waves break right in front of it. Dont
get caught inside.

name: Wariruri
description:
Wariruri is a bay located near the Bushiribana Goldmine Ruins on the
north coast of the island. A popular spot among surfers, Wariruri is a
place for all levels. Waves break both left and right and can reach faces
as high as six feet some times bigger. There are rocks on the left side and
far right side but other than that, its a pretty good rippable wave with
good sections. On big days, the current can get strong and it can be
difficult to get out in to the line up. On the far left side of the bay,
there is a left peak which breaks on dry reef. Dont get caught on the left
side of the bay or youll be into the rocks.
